The former judge of the Great British Bake Off and the nation's favourite TV food expert has had her say on how cream teas should be made - and it might just be genius.
It is the fiercest debate in cross-border politics between Devon and Cornwall with the Cornish making their cream teas scone, jam, cream - while in Devon it is scone, cream, jam.
Some of the most influential voices in the world have had their say on the ancient grudge - with Prince Charles pointing out cream teas made the 'wrong' (Devon) way when he was at the Royal Cornwall Show. Read More
Then this week Philip Schofield shared a picture of his favourite cream teas - made the Devon way - and prompted a social media backlash.
Schofe grew up in Cornwall and started his media career in Devon. Mary Berry at her house in Salcombe
So what does the Queen of the Kitchen, who has a home in Salcombe, have to say?
The 83-year-old Theresa May of Devon and Cornwall's answer to Brexit has found a third way. Read More
Her revelation came as she hosted the Cath Kidston World's Largest Cream Tea Party at Alexandra Palace in north London. poll loading Which is the right way up? 500+ VOTES SO FAR Jam first Cream first
Berry told Country Living that she has a plan that doesn't 'upset anyone in either Devon or Cornwall'.
When she splits her scone in half (and she says it should be scone to rhyme with gone) she spreads jam first on one half, and cream first on the other.
Evil, or genius?
